sect1.title: Playing &app;
sect1.para: &app; is a puzzle game. The goal is to remove as many objects as possible in as few moves as possible. Objects that are adjacent to each other get removed as a group, then the remaining objects collapse to fill in the gaps and make new groups. You can't remove single objects.

figure.title: &app; at the beginning of a new game.

sect1.para: The board starts as a full grid of objects. Depending on the size of board you select, there are either three or four types of object. If a group of objects are adjacent and all the same type, then they can be removed simply by clicking them with the mouse (or by pressing the space bar). The objects in a group will start spinning when the mouse moves over them. The number of objects, and the points you will score for removing that group, is shown in the lower left corner of the window. The more objects in the group, the more points you score. Once the group has been removed the objects above them fall down to fill the space. If an entire column is cleared then the objects slide leftward to fill the gap.
Scoring is based on the number of objects you delete:
For larger numbers the formula is p = (n - 2)2, where n is the number of objects and p the points scored.
If you clear all the objects there is a 1000 point bonus.

sect1.title: Customization
sect1.para: You can alter the look of the game and the size of the board. The former is done via the view menu and the later via the size menu.

sect2.title: Changing the Size
sect2.para: The Size menu contains three settings: small, medium and large. Aside from increasing the number of objects, the large setting also increases the number of different objects.

sect2.title: Changing the Look
sect2.para: You can change the look of the objects by using the Theme item in the View menu. You are presented with a list of the available styles.
To change the size of the individual objects, resize the window. To make the maximum use of the screen, choose the Fullscreen option from the View menu.

You can create your own themes. Use an existing theme as a template and put the result in $XDG_DATA_HOME/gnome-games/same-gnome/themes/2.10/. It will be automatically included on the themes list next time you run &app;. $XDG_DATA_HOME is usually ~/.local/share/.

sect1.title: Strategy
sect1.para: The most important rule when aiming for a high score is to think ahead: each group you remove will form and destroy other groups. Remove the higher group first, unless removing other groups will make it larger. Fortunately vertical groups can never be detroyed, but horizontal alignments change.

Because the score increases quadratically, big groups of objects are always better. For example, the points difference between a six object group and a seven object group is nine points. This means that in a situation where you have a choice between merging two groups of two into four or just adding one more to a group of six then you should go with the later option, even though you may score no points from the other balls. On the other hand, if even one of the groups of two can be merged with five or more it is better to sacrifice the group of six.

The thousand point bonus for clearing all the balls is also worth pursuing. To beat 1000 points you have to form a group of 34 objects. You are very unlikley to be in a position where you will have to choose between the two options.
